Lower pressure altitudes and lower temperatures.
Higher pressure altitudes and lower temperatures.

variant.question: A crew preparing for departure select an assumed temperature of 45 °C for the determining of takeoff thrust setting. The OAT is 20 °C. What is the performance implication from the difference between the selected temperature and the actual OAT?

options.text: Taking off with a selected temperature of 45 °C and an actual OAT of 20 °C would result in the same performance as if the OAT were 45 °C.
Taking off with a selected temperature of 45 °C and an actual OAT of 20 °C would result in the same performance as if the OAT were 20 °C.
There are no tangible differences between selecting an assumed temperature of 20 °C or 45 °C.
Taking off with a selected temperature of 45 °C and an actual OAT of 20 °C would result in improved performance than if a selected temperature of 20 °C were to be selected.

variant.question: For a performance class A aircraft the net take-off flight path is subdivided into various segments. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The first segment starts at the end of the TODR, where the aircraft should be 35 ft and V2. This segment is flown at V2 whilst the landing gear is retracted.
The third segment is completed at the normal flap retraction height and is flown at maximum continuous thrust until the flaps are retracted.

The final segment starts at the end of segment 3 with the aircraft in a clean configuration, at the en-route climb speed with maximum power set, ending at 1 500 ft or higher if there are distant obstacles to clear.
The second segment is flown at V3 up to a height of 400 ft (flap retraction height).

variant.question:
Performance Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.5
Consider the take-off performance for the twin jet aeroplane climb limit chart
Why has the wind been omitted from the chart?

options.text: The limitation presented in this chart is taken relative to air.
There is no effect of the wind on the climb angle relative to the ground.
There is a built-in safety measure.
The effect of the wind must be taken from another chart.

variant.question:
Which of the following combination correctly completes the sentence below, with regards to the effect of displacement drag and impingement drag on the take-off performance?
There is a (1) effect in case of a rejected take-off and a (2) effect for continued take-off.

options.text: (1) positive; (2) negative
(1) positive; (2) positive
(1) negative; (2) positive
(1) negative; (2) negative

variant.question:
Refer to figure 032-12.
Consider the take-off performance for the twin jet aeroplane climb limit chart. Why has the wind been omitted from the chart?

options.text: The climb limit performances are taken relative to the air.
There is a built-in safety measure.
There is no effect of the wind on the climb angle relative to the ground.
The effect of the wind must be taken from another chart.

variant.question:
Refer to the Annex or to Performance Manual MRJT 1 Figure 4.4. For a twin engine turbojet aeroplane two take-off flap settings (5° and 15°) are certified. Given:
  • Field length available: 2400 m
  • Outside air temperature: -10° C
  • Airport pressure altitude: 7000 ft
  • PMC: ON
  • A/C: Auto
  • Packs: ON
  • No wind and slope.
  • No anti-ice.
The maximum allowed take-off mass is:

Refer to figure 032-70.
An MRJT aeroplane is landing on runway 25 at an airport which has a long, dry runway with no restrictions. It is chosen because of its negligible taxi distance post landing. The planned turnaround time is 25 minutes. Given the following information, is this turnaround time achievable?


- Landing mass: 51 000 kg
- V~REF~: 132 kt
- Wind: 070°/6 kt (use 50% of headwind component or 150% of tailwind component as applicable)
- Elevation: 280 ft
- QNH: **1013.25** hPa
- OAT: +19 °C

options.text: Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with autobrake #1 or #2.
No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing and most conservative braking must be accounted for, requiring an inspection of the fuse plugs after 30 minutes.
Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with any autobrake setting.
No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing resulting in a minimum cooling time of approximately 60 minutes for the lowest autobrake settings #1 and #2.
